noun.description: A person or thing that prevents incompatible or antagonistic people or things from coming into contact with or harming each other.
examples: family and friends can provide a buffer against stress

noun.description: A solution that resists changes in pH when acid or alkali is added to it. Buffers typically involve a weak acid or alkali together with one of its salts.
A temporary memory area in which data is stored while it is being processed or transferred, especially one used while streaming video or downloading audio.

verb.description: Lessen or moderate the impact of (something)
examples: the massage helped to buffer the strain
add organic matter to buffer the resulting alkalinity

verb.description: Store (data) in a buffer while it is being processed or transferred.
examples: try buffering as much of the video stream as you can before you hit the 'play' button

origin: Mid 18th century: probably from obsolete buff (see buffer), or from dialect buff stutter, splutter (possibly the same word). In late Middle English buffer had the sense stammerer.
